TITLE: Configuring Flagger Canary for ZAP Integration
DESCRIPTION: This YAML configuration defines a Flagger Canary resource that integrates with ZAP. It includes webhooks for starting ZAP, running integration tests proxied through ZAP, and triggering ZAP scans after the canary deployment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-12-24-use-zap-with-flagger-in-kubernetes/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: flagger.app/v1beta1
kind: Canary
metadata:
  name: podinfo
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  provider: kubernetes
  targetRef:
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    name: podinfo
  # the maximum time in seconds for the canary deployment
  # to make progress before it is rollback (default 600s)
  progressDeadlineSeconds: 600
  service:
    port: 9898
    targetPort: http
    portDiscovery: true
  skipAnalysis: false
  analysis:
    # schedule interval (default 60s)
    interval: 30s
    # max number of failed metric checks before rollback
    threshold: 2
    # total number of iterations
    iterations: 2
    webhooks:
    - name: start zap
      type: confirm-rollout
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 3m
      metadata:
        type: bash
        cmd: "r=$RANDOM && kubectl create job -n zap-demo --from=cronjob/zap zap-job-${r} && kubectl wait --for=jsonpath='{.status.ready}'=1 -n zap-demo job/zap-job-${r} --timeout=2m"
    - name: integration test
      type: pre-rollout
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      metadata:
        cmd: "curl --proxy http://zap:8080 http://podinfo-canary:9898/api/info"
      timeout: 3m
    - name: load test
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 5s
      metadata:
        cmd: "hey -z 1m -q 10 -c 2 http://podinfo-canary:9898/"
    - name: run zap
      type: post-rollout
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 3m
      metadata:
        cmd: "curl http://zap:8080/JSON/automation/action/endDelayJob"
```

TITLE: Markdown Configuration Table
DESCRIPTION: Detailed table showing configuration options for the passive scanner, including field names, descriptions, default values and corresponding configuration file entries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/passive-scanner/options/scanner.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
|                         Field                         |                                                                                                                                                                                 Details                                                                                                                                                                                  |  Default   |                                      Config File                                      |
|-------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Only scan messages in scope                           | Sets whether or not the passive scan should be performed only on messages that are in scope.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             | Deselected | Key: `pscans.scanOnlyInScope` Values: `true` or `false`                               |
| Include traffic from the Fuzzer when passive scanning | Sets whether or not the passive scanning should be performed on messages generated by the Fuzzer.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | Deselected | Key: `pscans.scanFuzzerMessages` Values: `true` or `false`                            |
| Max alerts any rule can raise                         | Sets the maximum number of alerts a passive scan rule should raise. This may be slightly exceeded due to threading. This setting is typically only useful for automated scanning. Scan rules that exceed this value will be disabled and will need to be manually enabled if a new session is started.                                                                   | 0 (unset)  | Key: `pscans.maxAlertsPerRule` Values: `0`: unset or the maximum number of alerts     |
| Max body size in bytes to scan                        | Sets the maximum size request or response body size in bytes that the passive scanner will scan. This can be used if passive scan rules take too long scanning very large requests or responses. If set the number of ignored requests and responses are recorded in the stats using the keys `stats.pscan.reqBodyTooBig` and `stats.pscan.respBodyTooBig` respectively. | 0 (unset)  | Key: `pscans.maxBodySizeInBytes` Values: `0`: unset or the maximum body size in bytes |
```

TITLE: Defining ZAP CronJob for Security Scanning
DESCRIPTION: Kubernetes YAML manifest that defines a suspended CronJob for ZAP. This job will never run on schedule but will be used by Flagger to create ZAP Jobs on-demand during deployments. It includes volume mounts for configuration and report storage.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-12-24-use-zap-with-flagger-in-kubernetes/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: batch/v1
kind: CronJob
metadata:
  name: zap
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  schedule: "* * * * *"
  suspend: true
  jobTemplate:
    spec:
      backoffLimit: 0
      template:
        metadata:
          labels:
            app.kubernetes.io/name: zap
        spec:
          containers:
          - args:
            - ./zap.sh
            - -cmd
            - -autorun
            - /zap/config/af-plan.yaml
            - -host
            - 0.0.0.0
            - -config
            - api.disablekey=true
            - -config
            - api.addrs.addr.name=.*
            - -config
            - api.addrs.addr.regex=true
            image: ghcr.io/zaproxy/zaproxy:stable
            name: zaproxy
            ports:
            - containerPort: 8080
              name: zaproxy
              protocol: TCP
            startupProbe:
              failureThreshold: 3
              httpGet:
                path: /
                port: 8080
                scheme: HTTP
              initialDelaySeconds: 60
              periodSeconds: 10
              successThreshold: 1
              timeoutSeconds: 3
            volumeMounts:
            - mountPath: /zap/config
              name: config
            - mountPath: /zap/reports
              name: pvc
          restartPolicy: Never
          volumes:
          - name: config
            configMap:
              name: zap-config
          - name: pvc
            persistentVolumeClaim:
              claimName: zap-pvc
```

TITLE: Defining Testing Service (podinfo) Deployment and Service
DESCRIPTION: Kubernetes YAML manifest that defines a Deployment and Service for the podinfo application, which will be the test application that Flagger will coordinate for deployment and that ZAP will scan.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-12-24-use-zap-with-flagger-in-kubernetes/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: podinfo
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: podinfo
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: podinfo
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: podinfod
        image: ghcr.io/stefanprodan/podinfo:6.7.0
        ports:
        - name: http
          containerPort: 9898
          protocol: TCP
        command:
        - ./podinfo
        - --port=9898
        - --level=info
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: podinfo
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  type: ClusterIP
  selector:
    app: podinfo
  ports:
    - name: http
      port: 9898
      protocol: TCP
      targetPort: http
```

TITLE: Configuring Flagger Canary Deployment
DESCRIPTION: Defines a Flagger Canary resource for blue/green deployment strategy with ZAP integration. Includes webhooks for starting ZAP scans, load testing, and managing deployment transitions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-12-24-use-zap-with-flagger-in-kubernetes/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: flagger.app/v1beta1
kind: Canary
metadata:
  name: podinfo
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  provider: kubernetes
  targetRef:
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    name: podinfo
  progressDeadlineSeconds: 600
  service:
    port: 9898
    targetPort: http
    portDiscovery: true
  skipAnalysis: false
  analysis:
    interval: 30s
    threshold: 2
    iterations: 2
    webhooks:
    - name: start zap
      type: confirm-rollout
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 3m
      metadata:
        type: bash
        cmd: "r=$RANDOM && kubectl create job -n zap-demo --from=cronjob/zap zap-job-${r} && kubectl wait --for=jsonpath='{.status.ready}'=1 -n zap-demo job/zap-job-${r} --timeout=2m"
    - name: load test
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 5s
      metadata:
        cmd: "hey -z 1m -q 10 -c 2 http://podinfo-canary:9898/"
    - name: run zap
      type: post-rollout
      url: http://flagger-loadtester.zap-demo/
      timeout: 3m
      metadata:
        cmd: "curl http://zap:8080/JSON/automation/action/endDelayJob"
```

TITLE: Managing Script Variables in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: API actions for managing global and script-specific variables in ZAP scripts, including setting, clearing individual variables, and clearing all variables.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.8.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### ACTION script / clearGlobalVar

Clears the global variable with the given key.

### ACTION script / clearGlobalVars

Clears the global variables.

### ACTION script / clearScriptVar

Clears the variable with the given key of the given script. Returns an API error (DOES_NOT_EXIST) if no script with the given name exists.

### ACTION script / clearScriptVars

Clears the variables of the given script. Returns an API error (DOES_NOT_EXIST) if no script with the given name exists.

### ACTION script / setGlobalVar

Sets the value of the global variable with the given key.

### ACTION script / setScriptVar

Sets the value of the variable with the given key of the given script. Returns an API error (DOES_NOT_EXIST) if no script with the given name exists.
```

TITLE: Defining Node Structure in YAML for ZAP Sites Tree

```
    url:               # The URL it represents, present for all apart from the top node
    method:            # The HTTP method, present for all apart from the top node
    responseLength:    # The length of the response, where relevant
    statusCode:        # The HTTP status code, where relevant
    data:              # The names of the data parameters, if any, separated with '=&'s
    children:          # A list of child nodes, present for all nodes apart from the leaves
```

TITLE: API Actions Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Detailed specification of the generate action including all available parameters for report generation such as title, template, theme, and various filtering options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/report-generation/api.md#2025-04-10_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
* generate (title\* template\* theme description contexts sites sections includedConfidences includedRisks reportFileName reportFileNamePattern reportDir display): Generate a report with the supplied parameters.
    * title: Report Title
    * template: Report Template
    * theme: Report Theme
    * description: Report Description
    * contexts: The name of the contexts to be included in the report, separated by '\|'. For example, "Default Context\|My Context".
    * sites: The site URLs that should be included in the report, separated by '\|'.
    * sections: The report sections that should be included, separated by '\|'. View section names via API view `templateDetails
        (template*)`
    * includedConfidences: Confidences that should be included in the report, separated by '\|'. Accepted values are "False Positive", "Low", "Medium", "High", and "Confirmed".
    * includedRisks: Risks that should be included in the report, separated by '\|'. Accepted values are "Informational", "Low", "Medium", and "High".
    * reportFileName: The file name of the generated report. This value overrides the reportFileNamePattern parameter.
    * reportFileNamePattern: Report File Name Pattern. For example, `{{yyyy-MM-dd}}-ZAP-Report-[[site]]`.
    * reportDir: Path to directory in which the generated report should be placed.
    * display: Display the generated report. Either "true" or "false".
```

TITLE: Configuring exitStatus Job in ZAP Automation Framework
DESCRIPTION: YAML configuration for the exitStatus job that sets ZAP's exit code based on scan results. This job allows setting error/warning levels and customizing exit values. It's typically the last job in an automation plan.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/automation-framework/job-exitstatus.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
  - type: exitStatus                   # Sets the exit code based on scan results
    parameters:
      errorLevel:                      # String: Informational, Low, Medium, High, default: not set
      warnLevel:                       # String: Informational, Low, Medium, High, default: not set
      okExitValue:                     # Integer: Exit value if all ok, default 0
      errorExitValue:                  # Integer: Exit value if there are errors, default 1
      warnExitValue:                   # Integer: Exit value if there are warnings, default 2
 
```

TITLE: Creating Persistent Volume Claim for ZAP Reports

SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-12-24-use-zap-with-flagger-in-kubernetes/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: zap
  name: zap-pvc
  namespace: zap-demo
spec:
  accessModes:
  - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 50Mi
  storageClassName: dynamic-slrs-blob-fuse
```

TITLE: Solution Example for Expression Language Injection Prevention
DESCRIPTION: Code demonstration showing how to properly validate and encode data before it reaches the EL interpreter to prevent injection attacks. Special focus on detecting and handling metacharacters like ${} and #{} patterns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/alerts/90025.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
// Example of input validation and encoding
String userInput = request.getParameter("input");
// Validate input
if (userInput.contains("${")||userInput.contains("#{")) {
    throw new ValidationException("Invalid characters detected");
}
// Encode output
String encodedInput = StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(userInput);
```

TITLE: Checking if Resource is a .DS_Store File in ZAP Spider
DESCRIPTION: Method to determine if a discovered resource is a .DS_Store file by checking its file extension and validating the magic bytes at the beginning of the file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2023-09-08-ds-store-parsing/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
@Override
public boolean canParseResource(ParseContext ctx, boolean wasAlreadyParsed) {
    return ctx.getPath().endsWith(".DS_Store")
            && startsWith(ctx.getHttpMessage().getResponseBody().getBytes(), MAGIC_BYTES);
}
```

TITLE: Defining ZAP API Context Management Endpoints in YAML
DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet defines the context management endpoints for the ZAP API. It includes methods for creating, viewing, and modifying contexts, as well as managing include and exclude regexes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/sbom/spiderAjax.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
  context:
    - name: addContext
      description: 'Add a new context, with the given name in the current session.'      
    - name: addIncludeRegexs
      description: 'Add include regex(s) to context'      
    - name: addExcludeRegexs
      description: 'Add exclude regex(s) to context'      
    - name: excludeAllContextTechnologies
      description: 'Excludes all built in technologies from a context'      
    - name: excludeContextTechnologies
      description: 'Excludes technologies with the given names, separated by a comma, from a context'      
    - name: exportContext
      description: 'Exports the context with the given name to a file. If a relative file path is specified it will be resolved against the "contexts" directory in ZAP "home" dir.'      
    - name: importContext
      description: 'Imports a context from a file. If a relative file path is specified it will be resolved against the "contexts" directory in ZAP "home" dir.'      
    - name: includeAllContextTechnologies
      description: 'Includes all built in technologies in to a context'      
    - name: includeContextTechnologies
      description: 'Includes technologies with the given names, separated by a comma, to a context'      
    - name: newContext
      description: 'Creates a new context with the given name in the current session'      
    - name: removeContext
      description: 'Removes a context in the current session'      
    - name: removeExcludeRegexs
      description: 'Remove exclude regex(s) from context'      
    - name: removeIncludeRegexs
      description: 'Remove include regex(s) from context'      
    - name: setContextCheckingStrategy
      description: 'Set the checking strategy for a context.'
```

TITLE: Markdown API Documentation Structure
DESCRIPTION: Structured documentation showing the available API views and actions for custom payloads management in ZAP proxy, including parameter requirements and descriptions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/custom-payloads/api.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Views

* customPayloads(category): Lists all the payloads currently loaded (category, payload, enabled state). Optionally filtered by category.
* customPayloadsCategories: Lists all the available categories.

### Actions

* addCustomPayload (category*, payload): Adds a custom payload (enabled when added).
* disableCustomPayloads(category): Disables custom payloads. Optionally limited by category. (No category means all)
* enableCustomPayloads(category): Enables custom payloads. Optionally limited by category. (No category means all)
* enableCustomPayload (category*, payload): Enables a custom payload.
* disableCustomPayload (category*, payload): Disables a custom payload.
* removeCustomPayload (category*, payload): Removes a custom payload.

**Note: *** Required parameter.
```

TITLE: Defining Network API Actions in Markdown
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet lists the actions available in the Network API, including their parameters and descriptions. It covers operations for managing network configurations, certificates, and proxy settings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/network/api.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Actions

* addAlias (name\* enabled): Adds an alias for the local servers/proxies.
    * name: The name of the alias.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* addHttpProxyExclusion (host\* enabled): Adds a host to be excluded from the HTTP proxy.
    * host: The value of the host, a regular expression.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* addLocalServer (address\* port\* api proxy behindNat decodeResponse removeAcceptEncoding): Adds a local server/proxy.
    * address: The address of the local server/proxy.
    * port: The port of the local server/proxy.
    * api: If the ZAP API is available, true or false.
    * proxy: If the local server should proxy, true or false.
    * behindNat: If the local server is behind NAT, true or false.
    * decodeResponse: If the response should be decoded, true or false.
    * removeAcceptEncoding: If the request header Accept-Encoding should be removed, true or false.
* addPassThrough (authority\* enabled): Adds an authority to pass-through the local proxies.
    * authority: The value of the authority, can be a regular expression.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* addPkcs12ClientCertificate (filePath\* password\* index): Adds a client certificate contained in a PKCS#12 file, the certificate is automatically set as active and used.
    * filePath: The file path.
    * password: The password for the file.
    * index: The index of the certificate in the file, defaults to 0.
* addRateLimitRule (description\* enabled\* matchRegex matchString requestsPerSecond\* groupBy\*): Adds a rule to the rate limiter.
    * description: A description that allows you to identify the rule. Each rule must have a unique description.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
    * matchRegex: Determines if matchString is a regular expression or a plain string: true or false.
    * matchString: A plain string match is handled based on DNS conventions. If the string has one or two components. If matchRegex is true, this is a regular expression.
    * requestsPerSecond: The maximum number of requests per second.
    * groupBy: How to group hosts when applying rate limiting: rule or host
* generateRootCaCert: Generates a new Root CA certificate, used to issue server certificates.
* importRootCaCert (filePath\*): Imports a Root CA certificate to be used to issue server certificates.
    * filePath: The file system path to the PEM file, containing the certificate and private key.
* removeAlias (name\*): Removes an alias.
    * name: The name of the alias.
* removeHttpProxyExclusion (host\*): Removes an HTTP proxy exclusion.
    * host: The value of the host.
* removeLocalServer (address\* port\*): Removes a local server/proxy.
    * address: The address of the local server/proxy.
    * port: The port of the local server/proxy.
* removePassThrough (authority\*): Removes a pass-through.
    * authority: The value of the authority.
* removeRateLimitRule (description\*): Removes a rule from the rate limiter.
    * description: The description of the rule.
* setAliasEnabled (name\* enabled): Sets whether or not an alias is enabled.
    * name: The name of the alias.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setConnectionTimeout (timeout\*): Sets the timeout, for reads and connects.
    * timeout: The timeout, in seconds.
* setDefaultUserAgent (userAgent\*): Sets the default user-agent.
    * userAgent: The default user-agent.
* setDnsTtlSuccessfulQueries (ttl\*): Sets the TTL of successful DNS queries.
    * ttl: The TTL, in seconds. Negative number, cache forever. Zero, disables caching. Positive number, the number of seconds the successful DNS queries will be cached.
* setHttpProxy (host\* port\* realm username password): Sets the HTTP proxy configuration.
    * host: The host, name or address.
    * port: The port.
    * realm: The authentication realm.
    * username: The user name.
    * password: The password.
* setHttpProxyAuthEnabled (enabled\*): Sets whether or not the HTTP proxy authentication is enabled.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setHttpProxyEnabled (enabled\*): Sets whether or not the HTTP proxy is enabled.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setHttpProxyExclusionEnabled (host\* enabled\*): Sets whether or not an HTTP proxy exclusion is enabled.
    * host: The value of the host.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setPassThroughEnabled (authority\* enabled): Sets whether or not a pass-through is enabled.
    * authority: The value of the authority.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setRateLimitRuleEnabled (description\*, enabled\*): Set enabled state for a rate limit rule.
    * description: The description of the rule.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setRootCaCertValidity (validity\*): Sets the Root CA certificate validity. Used when generating a new Root CA certificate.
    * validity: The number of days that the generated Root CA certificate will be valid for.
* setServerCertValidity (validity\*): Sets the server certificate validity. Used when generating server certificates.
    * validity: The number of days that the generated server certificates will be valid for.
* setSocksProxy (host\* port\* version useDns username password): Sets the SOCKS proxy configuration.
    * host: The host, name or address.
    * port: The port.
    * version: The SOCKS version.
    * useDns: If the names should be resolved by the SOCKS proxy, true or false.
    * username: The user name.
    * password: The password.
* setSocksProxyEnabled (enabled\*): Sets whether or not the SOCKS proxy is enabled.
    * enabled: The enabled state, true or false.
* setUseClientCertificate (use\*): Sets whether or not to use the active client certificate.
    * use: The use state, true or false.
* setUseGlobalHttpState (use\*): Sets whether or not to use the global HTTP state.
    * use: The use state, true or false.
```

TITLE: New API Endpoints: break / setHttpMessage, continue, step, drop in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: New action endpoints have been added to manipulate intercepted messages, including overwriting, submitting, stepping through, or dropping them.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.6.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### ACTION break / setHttpMessage

Overwrites the currently intercepted message with the data provided.

### ACTION break / continue

Submits the currently intercepted message and unsets the global request/response breakpoints.

### ACTION break / step

Submits the currently intercepted message, the next request or response will automatically be intercepted.

### ACTION break / drop

Drops the currently intercepted message.
```

TITLE: Retrieving WebSocket Messages View in ZAP API

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### messages

Optional Parameters:

* channelId: the channel identifier
* start: the offset to start returning messages from, starting from 0.
* count: the number of messages to return.
* payloadPreviewLength: the maximum number bytes to return for the payload contents.

Returns a list of all of the messages that meet the given criteria - by default all messages are returned  
The channelId can be discovered via the 'channels' view.  
The 'start' and 'count' parameters can be used to page through the messages  
The 'payloadPreviewLength' can be used to restrict the size of the data returned.
```

TITLE: Configuring ZAP Replacer Rules via Command Line
DESCRIPTION: This extensive command line example shows how to set multiple replacer rules in ZAP, demonstrating the syntax for configuring array-like settings with multiple properties for each rule.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-do-you-find-out-what-key-to-use-to-set-a-config-value-on-the-command-line.md#2025-04-10_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: Bash
CODE:
```
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).description=auth1 \
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).enabled=true \
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).matchtype=REQ_HEADER \
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).matchstr=Authorization \
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).regex=false \
-config replacer.full_list\(0\).replacement=SBSBSB \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).description=auth2 \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).enabled=true \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).matchtype=REQ_HEADER \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).matchstr=AnotherHeader \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).regex=false \
-config replacer.full_list\(1\).replacement=BLAHBLAH
```

TITLE: Defining Network API Views in Markdown
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet lists the views available in the Network API. These views allow retrieving various network configurations and settings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/network/api.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Views

* getAliases: Gets the aliases used to identify the local servers/proxies.
* getConnectionTimeout: Gets the connection timeout, in seconds.
* getDefaultUserAgent: Gets the default user-agent.
* getDnsTtlSuccessfulQueries: Gets the TTL (in seconds) of successful DNS queries.
* getHttpProxy: Gets the HTTP proxy.
* getHttpProxyExclusions: Gets the HTTP proxy exclusions.
* getLocalServers: Gets the local servers/proxies.
* getPassThroughs: Gets the authorities that will pass-through the local proxies.
* getRateLimitRules: Gets the rate limit rules.
* getRootCaCertValidity: Gets the Root CA certificate validity, in days. Used when generating a new Root CA certificate.
* getServerCertValidity: Gets the server certificate validity, in days. Used when generating server certificates.
* getSocksProxy: Gets the SOCKS proxy.
* isHttpProxyAuthEnabled: Tells whether or not the HTTP proxy authentication is enabled.
* isHttpProxyEnabled: Tells whether or not the HTTP proxy is enabled.
* isSocksProxyEnabled: Tells whether or not the SOCKS proxy is enabled.
* isUseGlobalHttpState: Tells whether or not to use global HTTP state.
```

TITLE: Raising Alerts with Overridden Metadata in ZAP Scripts
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to raise an alert in a ZAP script while overriding specific metadata fields. It shows how to set evidence and other information while inheriting the rest from the metadata.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2024-07-17-script-scan-rules/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
function scan(helper, msg, src) {
  // ... 
  foundKeys = ["my-secret-key", "my-other-secret-key"]
  helper
    .newAlert()
    .setEvidence(foundKeys[0])
    .setOtherInfo(`Other instances: ${foundKeys.slice(1).toString()}`)
    .setMessage(msg)
    .raise();
}
```

TITLE: Creating an Alert in ZAP Passive Scan Rule
DESCRIPTION: Example of how to create and populate an Alert object in a ZAP passive scan rule. This shows the various fields that can be set to describe a potential vulnerability.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2014-04-03-hacking-zap-3-passive-scan-rules/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Java
CODE:
```
Alert alert = new Alert(pluginId);
alert.setName(name);
alert.setRisk(Alert.RISK_LOW);
alert.setConfidence(Alert.CONFIDENCE_MEDIUM);
alert.setDescription(description);
alert.setUri(uri);
alert.setParam(param);
alert.setOtherInfo(otherInfo);
alert.setSolution(solution);
alert.setReference(reference);
alert.setEvidence(evidence);
alert.setCweId(cweId);
alert.setWascId(wascId);
```

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:

```
---
title: "Buffer Overflow"
alertid: 30001
alertindex: 3000100
alerttype: "Active"
alertcount: 1
status: release
type: alert
risk: Medium
solution: "Rewrite the background program using proper return length checking. This will require a recompile of the background executable."

other: "Potential Buffer Overflow. The script closed the connection and threw a 500 Internal Server Error."
cwe: 120
wasc: 7
techtags: 
  - Language.C
alerttags:
```

TITLE: Implementing Session Management Script for OWASP Juice Shop in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: A JavaScript session management script for OWASP Juice Shop that handles JWT token authentication. It extracts tokens from responses, clears session identifiers, and processes messages to include authentication tokens in requests.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2020-06-04-zap-2-9-0-highlights/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
/*
 * Session Management script for OWASP Juice Shop
 * 
 * For Authentication select:
 * 		Authentication method:		JSON-based authentication
 * 		Login FORM target URL:		http://localhost:3000/rest/user/login
 * 		URL to GET Login Page:		http://localhost:3000/
 * 		Login Request POST data:	{"email":"test@test.com","password":"test1"}
 * 		Username Parameter:			email
 * 		Password Parameter:			password
 * 		Logged out regex:			\Q{"user":{}}\E
 * 
 * Obviously update with any local changes as necessary.
 */

var COOKIE_TYPE   = org.parosproxy.paros.network.HtmlParameter.Type.cookie;
var HtmlParameter = Java.type('org.parosproxy.paros.network.HtmlParameter')
var ScriptVars = Java.type('org.zaproxy.zap.extension.script.ScriptVars');

function extractWebSession(sessionWrapper) {
	// parse the authentication response
	var json = JSON.parse(sessionWrapper.getHttpMessage().getResponseBody().toString());
	var token = json.authentication.token;
	// save the authentication token
	sessionWrapper.getSession().setValue("token", token);
	ScriptVars.setGlobalVar("juiceshop.token", token);
}
    	
function clearWebSessionIdentifiers(sessionWrapper) {
	var headers = sessionWrapper.getHttpMessage().getRequestHeader();
	headers.setHeader("Authorization", null);
	ScriptVars.setGlobalVar("juiceshop.token", null);
}
    	
function processMessageToMatchSession(sessionWrapper) {
	var token = sessionWrapper.getSession().getValue("token");
	if (token === null) {
		print('JS mgmt script: no token');
		return;
	}
	var cookie = new HtmlParameter(COOKIE_TYPE, "token", token);
	// add the saved authentication token as an Authentication header and a cookie
	var msg = sessionWrapper.getHttpMessage();
	msg.getRequestHeader().setHeader("Authorization", "Bearer " + token);
	var cookies = msg.getRequestHeader().getCookieParams();
	cookies.add(cookie);
	msg.getRequestHeader().setCookieParams(cookies);
}

function getRequiredParamsNames() {
	return []; 
}

function getOptionalParamsNames() {
	return [];
}
```

TITLE: Subscribing to ZAP Alert Events with Discord Integration
DESCRIPTION: A JavaScript Extender script that subscribes to ZAP's internal alert events and forwards them to Discord via a webhook. When ZAP raises an alert, the script formats the alert details including name, URL, risk level, and confidence, then sends them to Discord as a formatted message.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2022-09-13-zap-extender-scripts/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
var discordWebHookUrl = "<Replace with Discord Webhook URL>"

var HttpSender = Java.type("org.parosproxy.paros.network.HttpSender")
var HttpMessage = Java.type("org.parosproxy.paros.network.HttpMessage")
var HttpHeader = Java.type("org.parosproxy.paros.network.HttpHeader")
var HttpRequestHeader = Java.type("org.parosproxy.paros.network.HttpRequestHeader")
var URI = Java.type("org.apache.commons.httpclient.URI")

function consumer(event) {
    if (event.getEventType() != "alert.added") return
    print(event.getParameters().get("name"))
    var params = event.getParameters()
    alert = {
        "fields": [
            { "name": "Alert :triangular_flag_on_post:", "value": params.get("name") },
            { "name": "URL", "value": "`" + params.get("uri") + "`" },
            { "name": "Risk", "value": params.get("riskString"), "inline": true },
            { "name": "Confidence", "value": params.get("confidenceString"), "inline": true }
        ]
    }
    var body = { "content": "", "embeds": [alert] }
    body = JSON.stringify(body)

    var requestMethod = HttpRequestHeader.POST
    var msg = new HttpMessage()
    msg.setRequestHeader(new HttpRequestHeader(requestMethod, new URI(discordWebHookUrl, true), HttpHeader.HTTP11))
    msg.getRequestHeader().setHeader(HttpHeader.CONTENT_TYPE, HttpHeader.JSON_CONTENT_TYPE)
    msg.getRequestHeader().setHeader(HttpHeader.CONTENT_LENGTH, String(body.length))
    msg.setRequestBody(body)
    var sender = new HttpSender(HttpSender.MANUAL_REQUEST_INITIATOR)
    sender.sendAndReceive(msg)
    print(msg.getResponseBody().toString())
}

function install(helper) {
    org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP.getEventBus().registerConsumer(consumer, "org.zaproxy.zap.extension.alert.AlertEventPublisher")
}

function uninstall(helper) {
    org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP.getEventBus().unregisterConsumer(consumer)
}
```

TITLE: Managing HTTP Session Tokens in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: API actions for handling default session tokens in ZAP's HTTP Sessions module, including adding, removing, and enabling/disabling session tokens.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.8.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### ACTION httpSessions / addDefaultSessionToken

Adds a default session token with the given name and enabled state.

### ACTION httpSessions / removeDefaultSessionToken

Removes the default session token with the given name.

### ACTION httpSessions / setDefaultSessionTokenEnabled

Sets whether or not the default session token with the given name is enabled.
```

```
function loadfile(filename){
        var filetype = filename.split('.'').pop();
        switch (filetype){
        case "js":
                var insert=document.createElement('script')
                insert.setAttribute("type","text/javascript")
                insert.setAttribute("src", filename)
                break;
        case 'css':
        var insert=document.createElement("link");
        insert.setAttribute("type", "text/css")
        insert.setAttribute("href", filename)
        insert.setAttribute("rel", "stylesheet")
        break;
        }
        if (typeof insert!="undefined")
        document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(insert);
        return false;
}


////The following is from:
//http://stackoverflow.com/questions/316781/how-to-build-query-string-with-javascript

function form_to_params( form )
{
        var output = "";
        var length = form.elements.length
        for( var i = 0; i < length; i++ )
        {
        element = form.elements[i]

        if(element.tagName == 'TEXTAREA' )
        {
                output += "|" + element.name + ":" + element.value; 
        }
        else if( element.tagName == 'INPUT' )
        {
                switch(element.type){
                case 'radio':
                case 'checkbox':
                        if(element.checked && !element.value){
                        output += "|" + element.name + ":on";
                        break;
                        }
                case 'text':
                case 'hidden':
                case 'password':
                        if(element.value)
                        output += "|" + element.name + ":" + element.value;
                break;     
                }
        }
        }
        return output.substring(1);
}


function htmlEntities(str) {
        return String(str).replace(/&/g, '&').replace(/</g, '<').replace(/>/g, '>').replace(/"/g, '"');
}</responsebody>
```

TITLE: YAML Alert Configuration
DESCRIPTION: YAML frontmatter configuration for the SameSite cookie attribute protection alert, including risk level, solution guidance, and references.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/alerts/100005.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
---
title: "SameSite Cookie Attribute Protection Used"
alertid: 100005
alertindex: 10000500
alerttype: "Script Passive"
alertcount: 1
status: alpha
type: alert
risk: Informational
solution: "CSRF possible vulnerabilities presents on the site will be mitigated depending on the browser used by the user (browser defines the support level for this cookie attribute). "
references:
   - https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-first-party-cookies
   - https://chloe.re/2016/04/13/goodbye-csrf-samesite-to-the-rescue
other: ""
cwe: 352
wasc: 9
alerttags: 
  - CWE-352
code: https://github.com/zaproxy/community-scripts/blob/main/passive/detect_samesite_protection.js
linktext: "passive/detect_samesite_protection.js"
help: https://www.zaproxy.org/docs/desktop/addons/community-scripts/
---
```

TITLE: Configuring Passive Scanner Options in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: This table presents the configuration options for the passive scanner in ZAP, including field names, descriptions, default values, and corresponding configuration file keys.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/ui/dialogs/options/pscanner.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
|                         Field                         |                                                                                                                                                                                 Details                                                                                                                                                                                  |  Default   |                                      Config File                                      |
|-------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Only scan messages in scope                           | Sets whether or not the passive scan should be performed only on messages that are [in scope](/docs/desktop/start/features/scope/).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      | Deselected | Key: `pscans.scanOnlyInScope` Values: `true` or `false`                               |
| Include traffic from the Fuzzer when passive scanning | Sets whether or not the passive scanning should be performed on messages generated by the Fuzzer.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | Deselected | Key: `pscans.scanFuzzerMessages` Values: `true` or `false`                            |
| Max alerts any rule can raise                         | Sets the maximum number of alerts a passive scan rule should raise. This may be slightly exceeded due to threading. This setting is typically only useful for automated scanning. Scan rules that exceed this value will be disabled and will need to be manually enabled if a new session is started.                                                                   | 0 (unset)  | Key: `pscans.maxAlertsPerRule` Values: `0`: unset or the maximum number of alerts     |
| Max body size in bytes to scan                        | Sets the maximum size request or response body size in bytes that the passive scanner will scan. This can be used if passive scan rules take too long scanning very large requests or responses. If set the number of ignored requests and responses are recorded in the stats using the keys `stats.pscan.reqBodyTooBig` and `stats.pscan.respBodyTooBig` respectively. | 0 (unset)  | Key: `pscans.maxBodySizeInBytes` Values: `0`: unset or the maximum body size in bytes |
| Clear Queue                                           | Empties the passive scan queue without passively scanning the messages. Currently running rules will run to completion but new rules will only be run when new messages are added to the queue.                                                                                                                                                                          |            |                                                                                       |
```

DESCRIPTION: This markdown table shows pre-defined timestamp formats available in ZAP's Output Tabs Time Stamp Options. It includes Long & Default, ISO8601, and Time Only formats with their corresponding Java SimpleDateFormat patterns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/ui/dialogs/options/view.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

```
|                 |                        |
|-----------------|------------------------|
| Long \& Default | yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss    |
| ISO8601         | yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ssZ |
| Time Only       | HH:mm:ss               |
```

TITLE: Accessing Custom Script Variables in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to set and get custom script variables in JavaScript. Shows both script-specific and global variables using the ScriptVars Java type, including examples of storing complex data types like objects and arrays.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.9.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
var ScriptVars = Java.type("org.zaproxy.zap.extension.script.ScriptVars")

ScriptVars.setScriptCustomVar(this.context, "var.name", {x: 1, y: 3})
print(ScriptVars.getScriptCustomVar(this.context, "var.name").y) // Prints 3

ScriptVars.setGlobalCustomVar("var.name", ["A", "B", "C", "D"])
print(ScriptVars.getGlobalCustomVar("var.name")[2]) // Prints C
```

TITLE: Defining OWASP Security Standards References in ZAP Reports
DESCRIPTION: This XML structure defines references to OWASP security standards within a ZAP security report. It includes links to OWASP Top 10 (2017 A6 and 2021 A5) for Security Misconfiguration and Web Security Testing Guide for Cookie Attributes testing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/report-generation/report-traditional-xml-plus.md#2025-04-10_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<tag>OWASP_2017_A06 </tag>
<link>https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A6_2017-Security_Misconfiguration.html </link>
</tag>
<tag>
<tag>OWASP_2021_A05 </tag>
<link>https://owasp.org/Top10/A05_2021-Security_Misconfiguration/ </link>
</tag>
<tag>
<tag>WSTG-v42-SESS-02 </tag>
<link>https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/v42/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/06-Session_Management_Testing/02-Testing_for_Cookies_Attributes </link>
</tag>

</tags>
</alertitem>
</alerts>
</site>
</OWASPZAPReport>
```

TITLE: Generated Python Parser Code from Kaitai Struct GIF Specification
DESCRIPTION: The Python code automatically generated by Kaitai Struct compiler from the GIF specification. This demonstrates how Kaitai Struct converts high-level format descriptions into working parser code with validation, proper type handling, and hierarchical data structures.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2023-09-08-ds-store-parsing/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This is a generated file! Please edit source .ksy file and use kaitai-struct-compiler to rebuild

import kaitaistruct
from kaitaistruct import KaitaiStruct, KaitaiStream, BytesIO


if getattr(kaitaistruct, 'API_VERSION', (0, 9)) < (0, 9):
    raise Exception("Incompatible Kaitai Struct Python API: 0.9 or later is required, but you have %s" % (kaitaistruct.__version__))

class Gif(KaitaiStruct):
    def __init__(self, _io, _parent=None, _root=None):
        self._io = _io
        self._parent = _parent
        self._root = _root if _root else self
        self._read()

    def _read(self):
        self.header = Gif.Header(self._io, self, self._root)
        self.logical_screen = Gif.LogicalScreen(self._io, self, self._root)

    class Header(KaitaiStruct):
        def __init__(self, _io, _parent=None, _root=None):
            self._io = _io
            self._parent = _parent
            self._root = _root if _root else self
            self._read()

        def _read(self):
            self.magic = self._io.read_bytes(3)
            if not self.magic == b"\x47\x49\x46":
                raise kaitaistruct.ValidationNotEqualError(b"\x47\x49\x46", self.magic, self._io, u"/types/header/seq/0")
            self.version = self._io.read_bytes(3)


    class LogicalScreen(KaitaiStruct):
        def __init__(self, _io, _parent=None, _root=None):
            self._io = _io
            self._parent = _parent
            self._root = _root if _root else self
            self._read()

        def _read(self):
            self.image_width = self._io.read_u2le()
            self.image_height = self._io.read_u2le()
            self.flags = self._io.read_u1()
            self.bg_color_index = self._io.read_u1()
            self.pixel_aspect_ratio = self._io.read_u1()
```

```
title: "Information Disclosure - Information in Browser Storage"
alertid: 120000
alertindex: 12000000
alerttype: "Client Passive"
status: alpha

   120000-1:
      alertid: 120000-1
      name: "Information Disclosure - Information in Browser localStorage"
   120000-2:
      alertid: 120000-2
      name: "Information Disclosure - Information in Browser sessionStorage"
```

TITLE: Configuring ZAP Docker Image with Java 11
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure a Docker image for ZAP using Java 11 as the base. It sets up environment variables for the ZAP home directory and downloads the weekly release.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/sbom/oast.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: dockerfile
CODE:
```
FROM gcr.io/distroless/java11-debian11

ENV ZAP_HOME /zap/wrk/

RUN wget -qO- https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/releases/download/w2023-05-15/ZAP_WEEKLY_D-2023-05-15.zip | jar xv \
    && mv ZAP_D* zap \
    && cd zap \
    && rm -rf zap.bat zap.ico zap.sh
```

TITLE: Advanced ZAP Security Scan Configuration in C#
DESCRIPTION: Extended implementation showing custom configuration options including URL exclusions, rule disabling, and user authentication. Demonstrates how to configure specific scan rules and add custom assertions using SARIF report data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2023-12-08-automated-zap-scans-for-orchard-core-apps/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
[Fact]
public Task SecurityScanWithCustomConfigurationShouldPass() =>
    ExecuteTestAfterSetupAsync(
        context => context.RunAndAssertBaselineSecurityScanAsync(
            configuration => configuration
                .ExcludeUrlWithRegex(".*blog.*")
                .DisablePassiveScanRule(
                    10037,
                    "Server Leaks Information via \"X-Powered-By\" HTTP Response Header Field(s)")
                .DisableScanRuleForUrlWithRegex(
                    ".*/about",
                    10038,
                    "Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set")
                .SignIn(),
            sarifLog => sarifLog.Runs[0].Results.Count.ShouldBeLessThan(34)));
```

TITLE: Configuring requestor Job in YAML for ZAP Automation Framework
DESCRIPTION: This YAML configuration defines a requestor job in ZAP's Automation Framework. It allows sending custom requests to specified URLs with optional parameters such as method, headers, data, and expected response code. The job can also use authenticated requests with a specified user.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/automation-framework/job-requestor.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
  - type: requestor                    # Used to send specific requests to targets
    parameters:
      user:                            # String: An optional user to use for authenticated requests, must be defined in the env
    requests:                          # A list of requests to make
      - url:                           # String: A mandatory URL of the request to be made
        name:                          # String: Optional name for the request, for documentation only
        method:                        # String: A non-empty request method, default: GET
        httpVersion:                   # String: The HTTP version to send the request with, default: HTTP/1.1
        headers:                       # An optional list of additional headers to include in the request
            - "header1:value1"
        data:                          # String: Optional data to send in the request body, supports vars
        responseCode:                  # Int: An optional, expected response code against which the actual response code will be matched
```

TITLE: ZAP Configuration File Content Example
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the content of a ZAP configuration file (named 'conf' in this example) that sets multiple replacer rules. Each line represents a single configuration option in dot notation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-do-you-find-out-what-key-to-use-to-set-a-config-value-on-the-command-line.md#2025-04-10_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
replacer.full_list(0).description=auth1
replacer.full_list(0).enabled=true
replacer.full_list(0).matchtype=REQ_HEADER
replacer.full_list(0).matchstr=Authorization
replacer.full_list(0).regex=false
replacer.full_list(0).replacement=SBSBSB
replacer.full_list(1).description=auth2
replacer.full_list(1).enabled=true
replacer.full_list(1).matchtype=REQ_HEADER
replacer.full_list(1).matchstr=AnotherHeader
replacer.full_list(1).regex=false
replacer.full_list(1).replacement=BLAHBLAH
```

TITLE: New API Endpoints: break / isBreakAll, isBreakRequest, isBreakResponse in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: New view endpoints have been added to check the current break status for all, request, and response breakpoints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.6.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### VIEW break / isBreakAll

Returns True if ZAP will break on both requests and responses.

### VIEW break / isBreakRequest

Returns True if ZAP will break on requests.

### VIEW break / isBreakResponse

Returns True if ZAP will break on responses.
```

TITLE: Proxying POST Request through ZAP using curl on Unix-like Systems
DESCRIPTION: This bash script demonstrates how to use curl to send a POST request through ZAP as a proxy. It sets up the proxy environment variables and uses curl to send a JSON payload to a specified URL.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-can-you-import-post-requests.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
export http_proxy=http://localhost:8080/
export https_proxy=http://localhost:8080/

curl -k -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"name": "ZAP", "reason": "test"}' \
    https://www.example.com
```

TITLE: Using Custom Global and Script Variables
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use custom variables that can store complex data types like objects and arrays, available in ZAP versions after 2.8.0.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/script-console/_index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
var ScriptVars = Java.type("org.zaproxy.zap.extension.script.ScriptVars")

ScriptVars.setScriptCustomVar(this.context, "var.name", {x: 1, y: 3})
print(ScriptVars.getScriptCustomVar(this.context, "var.name").y) // Prints 3

ScriptVars.setGlobalCustomVar("var.name", ["A", "B", "C", "D"])
print(ScriptVars.getGlobalCustomVar("var.name")[2]) // Prints C
```

TITLE: Direct URL Access to ZAP API Endpoints
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to directly access the ZAP API using URL endpoints. This example demonstrates calling the passive scan APIs to enable all scanners, which can be useful for scripting or when client libraries aren't available.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/sbom/graphql.md#2025-04-10_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
http://zap/JSON/pscan/action/enableAllScanners
```

TITLE: Retrieving Specific WebSocket Message View in ZAP API
DESCRIPTION: Returns full details of a specified WebSocket message. Requires channelId and messageId as mandatory parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/websockets/api.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### message

Mandatory Parameters:

* channelId: the channel identifier
* messageId: the message identifier

Returns full details of the specified message.  
The 'channelId' and 'messageId' can be discovered via the 'messages' view.
```

TITLE: Increasing Logging Verbosity in ZAP (Properties)
DESCRIPTION: This configuration increases the logging level to 'debug' for the main ZAP packages, which significantly increases the amount of logging performed. This change requires restarting ZAP to take effect.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-do-you-configure-zap-logging.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: properties
CODE:
```
logger.paros.name = org.parosproxy.paros
logger.paros.level = debug

logger.zap.name = org.zaproxy.zap
logger.zap.level = debug
```

DESCRIPTION: Command line configuration to allow a specific IP address to connect to the ZAP API. This example shows how to permit connections from IP address 123.456.789.123.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-can-i-connect-to-zap-remotely.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell

```
-config api.addrs.addr.name=123.456.789.123
```

TITLE: Defining YAML Front Matter for Authentication Decision Tree Page
DESCRIPTION: YAML front matter that sets up the page structure for a decision tree question about application type for authentication purposes. It defines the title, page type, layout, question, and possible answers with corresponding links.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/authentication/what-app-type.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

```
---
title: "Auth: Application Type"
type: page
layout: decision-question
question: What type is your application?
answers:

  link: ../modern-web-ui/
- answer: 'API or Traditional web based UI'
  link: ../token-based-authentication/
---
```

TITLE: New API Endpoint: ascan / optionMaxScanDurationInMins in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: A new view endpoint has been added to retrieve the maximum time in minutes that a full scan can run. Zero indicates unlimited time.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.6.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### VIEW ascan / optionMaxScanDurationInMins

Returns the maximum time in minutes that a full scan can run for, zero is unlimited.
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Suspicious XML Comment Detection in WebSocket Payloads
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates how the Information Disclosure: Suspicious XML Comments script detects potentially sensitive comments in XML-formatted WebSocket message payloads. It shows both a true negative and a true positive case.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/websockets/pscanrules.md#2025-04-10_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
|                             Use case                             |    Outcome    |
|------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------|
| ``` <xml_test><!-- This is a comments section --></xml_test> ``` | True Negative |
| ``` <user_form><!-- FIXME: Encode --></user_form> ```            | True Positive |
```

TITLE: Configuring Documentation Page Structure in YAML
DESCRIPTION: YAML configuration defining the ZAP documentation page structure with three main sections: Guides, In Depth Features, and Internal Details. Each section contains links to specific documentation resources with descriptions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/_index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
---
type: page
title: Documentation
layout: group-links
groups:
  - header: 'Guides'
    links:
      - name: 'Getting Started Guide'
        link: /getting-started/
        desc: a good place to start if you are new to ZAP
    
      - name: 'Getting Further Guides'
        link: /docs/getting-further/
        desc: in depth guides covering different ways you can use ZAP
    
      - name: 'Desktop User Guide'
        link: /docs/desktop/
        desc: the help included with the ZAP desktop application 
    
      - name: 'ZAP Developer Guide'
        link: /docs/developer/
        desc: ZAP documentation for developers
    
      - name: 'Contributing Guide'
        link: /docs/contribute/
        desc: lots more details on how you can get involved 

      - name: 'FAQ'
        link: /faq/
        desc: Frequently Asked Questions 
    
      - name: 'ZAPping the OWASP Top 10 (2021)'
        link: /docs/guides/zapping-the-top-10-2021
        desc: a guide mapping Top 10 items to ZAP functionality that can assist IT security personnel

  - header: 'In Depth Features'
    links:
      - name: 'Automate'
        link: /docs/automate/
        desc: the various options for automating ZAP 
    
      - name: 'Authentication Decision Tree'
        link: /docs/authentication/
        desc: the best place to start if you need ZAP to authenticate to your app 
    
      - name: 'Docker'
        link: /docs/docker/
        desc: detailed information on ZAP's Docker images 
    
      - name: 'Burp to ZAP Feature Map'
        link: /docs/burp-to-zap-feature-map/
        desc: a mapping from Burp Suite features to their ZAP equivalents
            
      - name: 'Statistics'
        link: /docs/statistics/
        desc: public ZAP usage statistics
    
      - name: 'Software Bill of Materials'
        link: /docs/sbom/
        desc: ZAP add-on SBOMs
    
  - header: 'Internal Details'
    links:

      - name: 'Alert Details'
        link: /docs/alerts/
        desc: detailed information on the alerts ZAP can raise 

      - name: 'Constants'
        link: /docs/constants/
        desc: defined in the ZAP codebase that are exposed via the API and/or scripts 
    
      - name: 'Internal Events'
        link: /docs/internal-events/
        desc: detailed information on the internal events ZAP publishes 
    
      - name: 'Internal Statistics'
        link: /docs/internal-statistics/
        desc: detailed information on the internal statistics ZAP maintains 

      - name: 'Test Scans'
        link: /docs/scans/
        desc: the results of running ZAP vs well known deliberately vulnerable apps 
---
```

TITLE: New API Endpoint: ascan / optionMaxRuleDurationInMins in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: A new view endpoint has been added to retrieve the maximum time in minutes that a scan rule can run. Zero indicates unlimited time.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/releases/2.6.0.md#2025-04-10_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### VIEW ascan / optionMaxRuleDurationInMins

Returns the maximum time in minutes that a scan rule can run for, zero is unlimited.
```

TITLE: Viewing ZAP Log File for Weekly/Live Release
DESCRIPTION: Displays the ZAP log file in weekly or live Docker containers. These builds use a different directory location for logs compared to the stable version.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/docker/diagnosing-problems.md#2025-04-10_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
cat ~/.ZAP_D/zap.log
```

TITLE: macOS ZAP Path Location
DESCRIPTION: Default installation path for ZAP's shell script on macOS systems
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/cmdline.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
/Applications/ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh
```

TITLE: Configuring WebSocket Exclusions in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: This section explains how to exclude specific URLs from WebSocket processing in ZAP. It's useful for high-volume, performance-critical WebSocket connections. The exclusion can be applied to specific domains and ports.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/websockets/sessionproperties.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
## Exclude from WebSocket

This allows you to manage the URLs where WebSocket communication is not processed in ZAP.   
Although all messages from excluded URLs are forwarded, nothing is stored nor can you view them in the user interface. This feature is useful for high volume, performance critical WebSocket connections.   
You can differentiate on the port for one given domain, by using e.g.: *example.com:443* to exclude WebSocket connections from example.com only on port 443.
```

TITLE: Configuring Authentication Auto-Detection in ZAP Automation Framework
DESCRIPTION: YAML configuration example for setting up authentication auto-detection in a ZAP Automation Framework plan. Includes context configuration with browser-based authentication, auto-detect verification, session management, and user credentials.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/getting-further/authentication/auto-detection.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
---
env:
  contexts:
  - name: "simple-json"
    urls:
    - "http://localhost:9091/auth/simple-json"
    includePaths:
    - "http://localhost:9091/auth/simple-json.*"
    excludePaths: []
    authentication:
      method: "browser"
      parameters:
        loginPageUrl: "http://localhost:9091/auth/simple-json/"
        loginPageWait: 5
        browserId: "firefox-headless"
      verification:
        method: "autodetect"
    sessionManagement:
      method: "autodetect"
      parameters: {}
    users:
    - name: "test"
      credentials:
        username: "test@test.com"
        password: "password123"
```

TITLE: Implementing a Delay Logic for IP Block Bypass with JavaScript in ZAP
DESCRIPTION: This script handles IP block protection by tracking request count and pausing execution after every third request. It uses Java's Thread.sleep() method to wait for 60 seconds, allowing the IP block to expire before continuing with further requests. The script implements the Fuzzer HTTP Processor interface with all required functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/blog/2025-04-09-portswigger-labs-broken-brute-force-protection-ip-block/index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
// Auxiliary variables/constants needed for processing.
var count = 1;

var Thread = Java.type("java.lang.Thread");

/**
* Processes the fuzzed message (payloads already injected).
*
* Called before forwarding the message to the server.
*
* @param {HttpFuzzerTaskProcessorUtils} utils - A utility object that contains functions that ease common tasks.
* @param {HttpMessage} message - The fuzzed message, that will be forward to the server.
*/
function processMessage(utils, message) {
    try {
        print(count);

        if (count % 3 === 0) {
            print("Pausing for activated IP block...");
            Thread.sleep(60000); // Pause for 60 seconds
        }
    } catch (error) {
        print("Error in processMessage: " + error.message);
        throw error;
    }

    count++;
}

/**
* Processes the fuzz result.
*
* Called after receiving the fuzzed message from the server.
*
* @param {HttpFuzzerTaskProcessorUtils} utils - A utility object that contains functions that ease common tasks.
* @param {HttpFuzzResult} fuzzResult - The result of sending the fuzzed message.
* @return {boolean} Whether the result should be accepted, or discarded and not shown.
*/
function processResult(utils, fuzzResult) {
    return true;
}

/**
* This function is called during the script loading to obtain a list of the names of the required configuration parameters,
* that will be shown in the Add Message Processor Dialog for configuration. They can be used
* to input dynamic data into the script, from the user interface
*/
function getRequiredParamsNames() {
    return [];
}

/**
* This function is called during the script loading to obtain a list of the names of the optional configuration parameters,
* that will be shown in the Add Message Processor Dialog for configuration. They can be used
* to input dynamic data into the script, from the user interface
*/
function getOptionalParamsNames() {
    return [];
}

```

TITLE: Scanning WebSocket Messages for Application Errors in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This script template is used to scan WebSocket messages for application errors that may disclose sensitive information. It's part of the OWASP ZAP (Zed Attack Proxy) project's WebSocket passive scanning capabilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/alerts/110001.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
// This script template scans WebSocket messages for application errors.
// Paste or drop this script into the Scripts tree under "WebSocket Passive".

var SCAN_THRESHOLD = 400; // Don't scan payloads below this length
var ALERT_THRESHOLD = 2; // Alert after seeing at least this many errors
var ALERT_NAME = "Application Error Disclosure via WebSockets";

var errorCount = 0;

var errorPatterns = [
    /exception occurred/i,
    /error occurred/i,
    /(?:[a-z][a-z0-9_]*\.)*[a-z][a-z0-9_]*exception/i,
    /\bFatal error:\b/i,
    /\bstack trace:\b/i,
    /(?:[a-z][a-z0-9_]*\.)*[a-z][a-z0-9_]*Error:/i,
    /\.(?:js|php|py|rb):\d+/i,
    /Failed to load resource:/i,
    /(?:Microsoft OLE DB Provider for SQL Server|Microsoft SQL Native Client|SQL Server|Oracle)\b.{0,100}?\berror\b/i,
    /\b(?:Microsoft OLE DB Provider for SQL Server|Microsoft SQL Native Client|SQL Server|Oracle)\b.{0,100}?\bDriver\b/i,
    /\.(?:java|cs|php|vb):(?:line)? \d+/i,
    /\[Microsoft\]\[ODBC/i,
    /\[ODBC SQL Server Driver\]/i,
    /\[ODBC Driver Manager\]/i,
    /\[SQLServer JDBC Driver\]/i,
    /\[SqlException/i,
    /System\.Data\.OleDb\.OleDbException/i,
    /Error Executing Database Query/i,
    /Unclosed quotation mark after the character string/i,
    /Incorrect syntax near/i,
    /Sintaxis incorrecta cerca de/i,
    /Syntax error in string in query expression/i,
    /ADODB\.Field \(0x800A0BCD\)/i,
    /the used SELECT statements have different number of columns/i,
    /org\.postgresql\.util\.PSQLException/i,
    /java\.sql\.SQLException/i,
    /Unexpected end of command in statement/i,
    /pg_query\(\) \[:/i,
    /supplied argument is not a valid PostgreSQL result/i,
    /PostgreSQL\.{0,40}?ERROR/i,
    /Warning: pg_connect\(\)/i,
    /valid PostgreSQL result/i,
    /Npgsql\./i,
    /Driver:{ SQL Server }/i,
    /ORA-\d{5}:/i,
    /Oracle error/i,
    /Oracle.*?Driver/i,
    /\.php on line \d+/i,
    /Warning: include\(/i,
    /Warning: require_once\(/i,
    /function\.include/i,
    /Disallowed Parent Path/i,
    /function\.require/i,
    /Warning: main\(/i,
    /Warning: session_start\(/i,
    /Warning: getimagesize\(/i,
    /Warning: mysql_query\(/i,
    /Warning: mysql_fetch_array\(/i,
    /Warning: mysql_/i,
    /Warning: pg_connect\(/i,
    /Servlet\.Exception/i,
    /System\.Web\.UI\.WebControls\.TextBox/i,
    /\[Java\]\.lang/i,
    /\$_REQUEST\["comingfrom"\] ===/i,
    /A syntax error has occurred/i,
    /JDBC Driver/i,
    /JDBC Error/i,
    /JDBC MySQL/i,
    /JDBC SQL/i,
    /JDBC Oracle/i,
    /JDBC PostgreSQL/i,
    /Invocation of init method failed/i,
    /Incorrect syntax near/i,
    /Unterminated string constant/i,
    /Call to a member function/i,
    /Uncaught exception/i,
    /com\.sun\.org\.apache\.xalan\.internal\.xsltc\.trax/i,
    /TransformerFactoryImpl/i,
    /Error Occurred While Processing Request/i,
    /Microsoft VBScript compilation error/i,
    /Microsoft VBScript error/i,
    /\.js\(\d+,\d+\)/i,
    /(?:"[^"]*?"|'[^']*?')\.\w+(?:\.\w+)+\(\)\;/i,
    /\.\w+(?:\.\w+)+\(\)\;/i,
    /Exception occurred: \w+(?:\.\w+)+/i,
    /Error occurred: \w+(?:\.\w+)+/i,
    /\w+(?:\.\w+)+\(\)\;/i,
    /\btraceback\b/i,
    /\bcontext\b.*?\bclosure\b/i,
    /\bclosure\b.*?\bcontext\b/i,
    /\bstack trace\b/i,
    /\bReferenceError\b/i,
    /\bSyntaxError\b/i,
    /\bTypeError\b/i,
    /\bRangeError\b/i,
    /\bURIError\b/i,
    /\bEvalError\b/i,
    /\bError\b/i,
    /\bException\b/i,
    /\bfunction\b.*?\bthrow\b/i,
    /\bthrow\b.*?\bfunction\b/i,
    /\btry\b.*?\bcatch\b/i,
    /\bcatch\b.*?\btry\b/i,
    /\bfinally\b/i,
    /\bassert\b/i,
    /\braise\b/i,
    /\bthrows?\b/i,
    /\bcause\b/i,
    /\bstacktrace\b/i,
    /\bdebug\b/i,
    /\blog\b/i,
    /\berror\b/i,
    /\bwarning\b/i,
    /\binfo\b/i,
    /\btrace\b/i,
    /\bfatal\b/i,
    /\bcritical\b/i,
    /\bsevere\b/i,
    /\balert\b/i,
    /\bemergency\b/i,
    /\bpanic\b/i,
    /\bcrash\b/i,
];

function scan(helper, msg) {
    var payload = String(msg.getReadablePayload());

    if (payload.length < SCAN_THRESHOLD) {
        return;
    }

    for (var i = 0; i < errorPatterns.length; i++) {
        if (errorPatterns[i].test(payload)) {
            errorCount++;
            if (errorCount >= ALERT_THRESHOLD) {
                helper.newAlert()
                    .setRiskMedium()
                    .setConfidence(3) // High
                    .setName(ALERT_NAME)
                    .setDescription("An application error was detected in the WebSocket payload.")
                    .setParam(msg.getChannelId().toString())
                    .setMessage(msg)
                    .raise();
                return;
            }
        }
    }
}

function getWsPlugin() {
    return org.zaproxy.zap.extension.websocket.WebSocketPassiveScriptHelper.getWebSocketPassiveScriptHelper();
}

function scan(helper, msg) {
    scanWebSocket(getWsPlugin(), msg);
}

```

TITLE: Creating Dockerfile for ZAP with Chrome
DESCRIPTION: This Dockerfile extends the ZAP stable image to include Chrome. It updates the system, downloads and installs Chrome, and cleans up unnecessary files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/faq/how-do-i-use-chrome-with-zap-in-docker.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: dockerfile
CODE:
```
FROM --platform=linux/amd64 softwaresecurityproject/zap-stable:latest

USER root

RUN apt-get update && \
	wget -q https://dl.google.com/linux/direct/google-chrome-stable_current_amd64.deb && \
	apt-get install -y ./google-chrome-stable_current_amd64.deb && \
	rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

USER zap
```

TITLE: Defining Authentication Statistics in Markdown Table
DESCRIPTION: This markdown table defines various authentication statistics recorded by the add-on. Each statistic is associated with a specific state of authentication and is recorded on a per-site basis for all contexts in scope.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/authentication-statistics/_index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
|                                             |                                                                                   |
|---------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| stats.auth.*component*.state.noauth         | The context does not have an authentication method                                |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.nothtml        | Non HTML responses (which are unlikely to have logged in/out indicators)          |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.notsuccess     | Unsuccessful HTML responses (which are unlikely to have logged in/out indicators) |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.noindicator    | No logged in/out indicators have been defined                                     |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.loggedinandout | Both the logged in and out indicators present                                     |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.loggedin       | Just the logged in indicator present                                               |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.loggedout      | Just the logged out indicator present                                               |
| stats.auth.*component*.state.unknown        | Neither the logged in or out indicators present                                   |
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Authentication Components in Markdown Table
DESCRIPTION: This markdown table defines the various components that can be part of the authentication statistics. Each component represents a different aspect or module of ZAP that can interact with authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy-website/blob/main/site/content/docs/desktop/addons/authentication-statistics/_index.md#2025-04-10_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
|        |                                                              |
|--------|--------------------------------------------------------------|
| ascan  | Active Scanner                                               |
| auth   | Authentication                                               |
| fuzz   | Fuzzer                                                       |
| manual | Manual requests                                              |
| proxy  | Proxied requests                                             |
| spider | Spider                                                      |
| *id*   | The integer identifier of another component not listed above |
```
